awd_titl_txt: SHF: Small: Novel SW/HW Approximate Computing Methodologies with Case Studies on Biometric Security Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Biometric systems are increasingly deployed to meet the security demand of mobile, embedded and internet-of-things devices. The goal of this project is to devise techniques that lead to biometric systems with faster response time, less energy consumption and cost without compromising the accuracy and security. In addition to the main research goal, this project includes a comprehensive education and outreach plan that includes research experience for undergraduate students, interdisciplinary educational courses, outreach to high-school students, and tech transfer to industry. 

To achieve the goal of this project, new approximate computing techniques will be developed to simplify the hardware of biometric systems with little or no compromise to accuracy. The project investigates new methods for approximate logic circuit synthesis using Boolean matrix factorization, which leads to smooth trade-off between circuit complexity and quality of results. The project also investigates the use of reinforcement-learning techniques to navigate the space of potential approximate designs to identify the best ones. Finally, the proposal investigates the impact of using the proposed methods on case studies of end-to-end biometric systems, including fingerprinting, iris scanning, and 3D facial recognition.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project has pioneered innovative methodologies for software and hardware computing, enabling digital circuits to strike a balance between performance and power consumption using approximate computing techniques. Our results demonstrate a significant improvement in the energy efficiency of digital circuits, with a particular focus on iris recognition systems.

Intellectual Merits:

One of the notable contributions of the project is the development of a novel resource-efficient technique for iris recognition, harnessing the power of fully convolutional neural networks. Iris recognition systems are at the forefront of security technology, and our project has significantly improved their performance, cost-effectiveness, and energy efficiency.

Furthermore, our efforts have yielded an approximate computing technique for adaptive monitoring of human activity using wearable devices. This advancement allows wearables to monitor and recognize human activity in a much more energy-efficient manner.

In the realm of general circuits, our grant has led to innovative methods for synthesizing approximate circuits directly from their Boolean descriptions in a fully automated manner, employing Boolean Matrix Factorization (BMF). Additionally, we have demonstrated the feasibility of using BMF to create circuits capable of seamlessly toggling between exact and approximate modes during runtime, all while maintaining efficiency.

Our project has resulted in the release of three public domain tools: (i) BLASYS: A tool for approximate circuit synthesis; (ii) FCNiris: A resource-efficient solution for iris recognition; and (iii) BACS Benchmark Set: A standardized research benchmark set for approximate computing studies.

Moreover, our project has culminated in a comprehensive survey article on approximate logic synthesis techniques, published in the Proceedings of IEEE, which serves as a valuable resource for the research community. In total, our research efforts have yielded ten impactful articles, two book chapters, and an issued patent.

Broader Impacts:

Our project has not only advanced scientific knowledge but has also played a crucial role in mentoring and nurturing young talent. We have engaged three Ph.D. students, one Master's student, and three undergraduate students, some of whom hail from underrepresented groups. Notably, our undergraduate students have actively participated in the project, contributing as co-authors to several published articles.

Furthermore, our work has resulted in the issuance of a patent that leverages neural networks for iris recognition in security systems.

To encapsulate our collective knowledge and contributions, we have curated a major edited book on approximate computing. This comprehensive volume comprises 24 chapters that comprehensively cover the major techniques in the field of approximate circuit techniques.
